DGACM.relevance_comment: Para 13 directs the Secretary‑General to appoint a Secretary‑General of the Conference to assist the Conference and its President in organizing business and timetables. This is a clear Secretariat task; DGACM’s PPB states it provides procedural and technical secretariat support and organizes meeting timetables and services, so DGACM would implement this requirement.

Para 14 requires the Secretary‑General to assist in preparing the provisional agenda and the first draft of the Conference reports to the General Assembly. DGACM’s subprogramme work includes substantive/procedural secretariat support and preparation/distribution of parliamentary documentation, so it implements this obligation.

Para 15 instructs the Secretary‑General, at the Conference’s request, to provide professional assistance by preparing background papers, bibliographies and compiling data relevant to negotiations. This maps directly to DGACM’s documentation and substantive secretariat functions (translation/compilation of materials, briefing papers).

Para 16 states the Secretary‑General shall perform such other functions as are entrusted to him by these rules or by the Conference. Although broad, this is an explicit delegation to the Secretariat; DGACM, as the Secretariat’s conference management arm, implements many such functions per its PPB (conference servicing, documentation, multilingual support).

Para 17 requests the Secretary‑General to provide the staff and necessary assistance and services needed by the Conference and any subsidiary bodies. This is an explicit requirement to furnish personnel and services (interpretation, documentation, meeting support) that DGACM’s PPB describes as core responsibilities.

Para 22 requires that, when requested, the Secretariat provide unofficial summaries of informal meetings in the working languages. DGACM’s PPB identifies provision of verbatim reporting, summaries and multilingual meeting services — this paragraph mandates that Secretariat service.

Para 24 provides that the Secretariat shall provide assistance to subsidiary bodies, as requested, including preparation of unofficial summaries. This directly tasks the Secretariat with services that DGACM’s documentation and meeting services subprogrammes deliver.

Para 37 mandates that simultaneous interpretation, verbatim records of public plenary meetings and documents be provided in UN languages. DGACM’s PPB explicitly covers interpretation, verbatim reporting and multilingual documentation services, so this paragraph establishes obligations DGACM implements.

Para 40 requires that verbatim records and formal and other relevant documents be distributed to States normally within two weeks and made available for public use. This imposes a clear documentation/distribution duty on the Secretariat; DGACM’s documentation and publishing subprogrammes are responsible for meeting such timeliness and publication mandates.

Para 42 directs that communications from non‑governmental organizations to the Conference, President or Secretariat be retained by the Secretariat, made available to delegations on request and that a list be circulated. This assigns a records‑management and distribution task to the Secretariat that aligns with DGACM’s document handling and publication responsibilities.

Para 44 requires that drafts of Conference reports be prepared by the President with the assistance of the Secretary‑General and be made available to all member States at least two weeks before adoption. This explicitly tasks the Secretariat with assistance in drafting and timely distribution—functions reflected in DGACM’s PPB.
